## Research Project Requirements


The grading rubric follows the classical scientific journal article structure (i.e., Introduction, Method, etc...).

</br>

:::{.fragment} 

Your paper needs to follow APA formatting: 

<strong><center> Abstract &rarr; Introduction &rarr;  Method &rarr; Results &rarr; Discussion &rarr; References </center></strong>

:::

</br>

:::{.fragment}

<center> Every section of the article is necessary for the audience to fully understand the presented material. </center>

:::

## DOs and DON'Ts 


<center> <p style= "padding-bottom:20px;"> Finally, Some general advice on what to do and not do when presenting a journal article. </p> </center>


<style>
.vl {
  border-left: 3px solid #404040;
  height: 500px;
  position: absolute;
  left: 49%;
  margin-left: 10px;
  top: 30%;
}
</style>

<div class="vl"></div>

::: {layout-ncol="2"}

::: col

<center> **DOs** 

<ul style = "font-size: 30px">

:::{.fragment fragment-index="1"}

<li> Use lots of figures and tables (if you can). </li>

:::

:::{.fragment fragment-index="2"}

<li> Have slides with low word count. ([40 words tops?](https://www.siue.edu/sites/midweek-mentor/pages/2014/slides.shtml){preview-link="true"})</li>

:::

:::{.fragment fragment-index="3"}

<li> Make use of animations to present content *sequentially*. </li>


:::

:::{.fragment fragment-index="4"}

<li> Some journal articles have multiple experiments; follow this structure:<br> Method 1 &rarr;<span style="color:green"> **results 1** </span> &rarr; method 2 &rarr; results 2. </li>

:::

</ul>

</center>

:::


:::col

<center> **DON'Ts** 

<ul style = "font-size: 30px">

:::{.fragment fragment-index="1"}

<li>  Only use text.  </li> 

:::

:::{.fragment fragment-index="2"}

<li>  <p style= "padding-bottom:40px;"> Have [too much text](https://24slides.com/presentbetter/content/images/wordpress/2019/09/too-much-text.png){preview-link="true"} on a single slide. </p> </li> 

:::



:::{.fragment fragment-index="3"}

<li> <p style= "padding-bottom:40px;">  Present the whole slide at once. </p> </li>


:::

:::{.fragment fragment-index="4"}

<li>  Do not present multiple experiments this way: <br> Method 1 &rarr; <span style="color:red"> **Method 2** </span> &rarr; results 1 &rarr; results 2. </li>

:::

</ul>

</center>
:::


:::
## Report Grading Rubric {.smaller}

<center> The grading rubric is a divided in APA sections: </center>

</br>

::: {layout-ncol="3"}

:::{.fragment}
:::col
<center> <a href="#/abstract">**Title Page & Abstract:**</a> 
</br>
Includes APA formated Title page and short abstract (100-200 words) that describes behaviors/variables studied, population/sample and summary of results.   (**15~pts~**)
</center>
:::
:::

:::{.fragment}
:::col
<center> <a href="#/introduction">**Introduction:**</a>
</br>
Includes summary of each (three total) article (uses proper citation, discusses relevant findings in 2-3 sentences), 2-3 sentences that integrates the literature and states the research hypotheses with full pattern predicted. (**65~pts~**) </center>
:::
:::
:::{.fragment}
:::col
<center> <a href="#/method">**Method:**</a> 
</br>
Includes all APA-required sections. Describes study *participants*, *materials*, and *procedures* in past tense and with sufficient detail. (**35~pts~**)
</center>
:::
:::

:::

::: {layout-ncol="3"}

:::{.fragment}
:::col
<center> <a href="#/results">**Results:**</a> 
</br>
Includes APA table with univariate statistics as well as complete description of each RH (statment/implication, complete pattern of data, support or not, presentation of apa-style statistics).  (**90~pts~**)
</center>
:::
:::

:::{.fragment}
:::col
<center> <a href="#/discussion">**Discussion (& Proposal):**</a> 
</br>
The results are quickly summarized, and the main discussion points (i.e., possible explanation of results, implications, limitations) are identified in a clear and organized manner. Includes discussion of future directions for research including (at least two) new, related RHs. (**175~pts~**)
</center>
:::
:::
:::{.fragment}
:::col
<center> <a href="#/delivery">**References:**</a>
</br>
The student delivers the presentation in an engaging way, without using any notes. Some notes are fine, but *clearly reading from notes will result in high point deduction*. (**20~pts~**)
</center>
:::
:::
:::

:::

## Lab report structure and Formatting

![](images/Lab_report.png){.absolute top=-50 right=-50 width="100" height="100"}


Your full lab report *must* include the following sections:


::: {layout-ncol="2"}

:::col

<ul style = "font-size:23px;
             margin: 20px;">

:::{.fragment fragment-index="1"}
<li> <a href="#/title-page"> **Title page:** </a> This should be the *1^st^ page* of your lab report. </li>
:::

:::{.fragment fragment-index="2"}
<li> <a href="#/abstract"> **Abstract:** </a> This should be the *2^st^ page* of your lab report. </li>
:::

:::{.fragment fragment-index="3"}
<li> <a href="#/introduction-1"> **Introduction:** </a> This should be the *3^st^ page* of your lab report.  (suggested length: **1 to 1.5 pages**)</li>
:::

:::{.fragment fragment-index="4"}
<li> <a href="#/method-1"> **Method:** </a> This section should include "participants", "materials", and "procedure" as 3 subsections. (suggested length: **1 page**) </li>
:::

:::{.fragment fragment-index="5"}
<li> <a href="#/results-1"> **Results:** </a> Where you report you data analyses. (suggested length: **0.5 pages**) </li>
:::

:::{.fragment fragment-index="7"}
<li> <a href="#/discussion-1"> **Discussion:** </a> Interpretation of findings, limitations, future directions. (suggested length: **1 page**) </li>
:::

:::{.fragment fragment-index="8"}
<li> <a href="#/references"> **References:** </a> Where you include the full references of your in-text citations.</li>
:::


</ul>


:::


:::col
:::{.fragment fragment-index="9"}

<center> **Formatting** </center>



<p  style = "font-size:30px"> Lab reports *must* follow these formatting conventions: </p> 

<ul style = "font-size:25px;
             margin: 20px;">

<li>Times New Roman </li>
<li>12 pt font </li>
<li>3-4 pages long (not including Reference section) </li> 
<li>double-spaced </li>
<li>with 1-inch margins </li>  
<li>page numbers on top right-hand corner </li>
<li>running head on top left-hand corner </li>
<li>Section Headings must follow [APA headings conventions](https://apastyle.apa.org/style-grammar-guidelines/paper-format/headings){target="blank} </li>

</ul>

:::

:::

:::

## Abstract

![](images/Lab_report.png){.absolute top=-50 right=-50 width="100" height="100"}


[<a href="#/lab-report-structure-and-formatting"><i class="fa fa-home fa-sm" aria-hidden="true" style="color:#6971E0; position:absolute;"></i></a>]{.absolute top="99%" left="5%"}

<p style= "font-size:28px;"> According to the APA publication manual, "an abstract is a brief, comprehensive summary of the contents of the paper". Here's an example of an abstract: </p>

::: {layout-ncol="2"}

:::col

:::{.fragment fragment-index="1"}

<blockquote> <p align="justify" style = "font-size:18px; "> 
Intrinsic motivation (IM) refers to engaging in an activity
for the pleasure inherent in the activity. The present article presents a
tripartite model of IM consisting of IM to know (i.e., engaging in an
activity to experience pleasure while learning and trying to understand
something new), IM toward accomplishment (i.e., engaging in an activity
for the pleasure experienced when attempting task mastery), and IM to
experience stimulation (i.e., engaging in an activity for feelings of sensory
pleasure). The tripartite model of IM posits that each type of IM can
result from task, situational, and personality determinants and can lead
to specific types of cognitive, affective, and behavioral outcomes. The
purpose of this research was to test some predictions derived from this
model. Across 4 studies (Study 1: *N* = 331; Study 2: *N* = 113; Study 3:
*N* = 58; Study 4: *N* = 135), the 3 types of IM as well as potential determinants
and consequences were assessed. Results revealed that experiencing
one type of IM over the others depends in part on people’s personality
styles. Also, each type of IM was found to predict specific outcomes (i.e.,
affective states and behavioral choices). The implications of the tripartite
model of IM for motivation research are discussed. ([Carbonneau et al., 2012, abstract](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1467-6494.2011.00757.x){target="_blank"})
</p> </blockquote>

:::

:::{.fragment fragment-index="2"}

<p  style = "font-size:22px; "> Your abstracts should be *no longer than 250 words* and should include these points about the lab report: </p>

::: 

<ul style = "font-size:25px;
             margin: 20px;">
             
          
:::{.fragment fragment-index="2"}
<li> <span style="color:blue"> **Background about the topic:** </span> This is essentially a summary of your introduction. </li>
:::

:::{.fragment fragment-index="3"}
<li> <span style="color:red"> **Purpose/Hypotheses:** </span> Mention what the purpose of the study was or the hypotheses (if any). </li>
:::

:::{.fragment fragment-index="4"}
<li> <span style="color:orange"> **Method:** </span> Include some information about the sample composition and the method. </li>
:::  
  
:::{.fragment fragment-index="5"}
<li> <span style="color:brown"> **Results:** </span> A very brief snippet of the results; **in the case of your lab report, include statistics here (e.g., t-tests, ANOVAs)**.  </li>
:::  

:::{.fragment fragment-index="6"}
<li> <span style="color:magenta"> **Discussion:** </span> Briefly mention the most important implication/s of the results. </li>
:::  

:::{.fragment fragment-index="7"}
<li> <p  style = "font-size:18px; "> **as a general rule, spend 1 to 3 sentences for each of the points above** </p></li>
:::
</ul>

:::



:::

:::

## Introduction

The introduction serves many purpose. A good introduction should hit all of the following points:

::: {layout-ncol="2"}


:::{.column width="200%"}
<ul style = "font-size:25px;
             margin: 20px;">
             

:::{.fragment fragment-index="1"}

<li>  **Introduce the topic:** What is the general topic that the report is focusing on? </li>

:::

:::{.fragment fragment-index="2"}

<li>  **Background literature:** What research has been done on topic? DO NOT mention statistics or methods from other papers; rather, try to seamlessly incorporate findings to support your argument. </li>

:::

:::{.fragment fragment-index="3"}

<li>  **Why we are running the experiment:** The reason as to why the experiment we are running is important/interesting. This part has to **logically** stem from the background literature that you present! </li>

:::

:::{.fragment fragment-index="4"}

<li>  **variables and hypotheses:**  What are the hypotheses (may be 1 or more)? What are the variables of interest? </li>

:::




</ul>

:::{.fragment fragment-index="5"}
<p style="font-size:28px;"> **For your introduction, you must cite at least <span style="color:red;"> 3 </span> sources.** </p>
:::

:::



:::{.column width="100%"}

:::{.fragment fragment-index="6"}

![](images/Funnel.png){width="250px"}

<p align="justify" style="font-size:22px;"> Much Like a funnel, your introduction should start very general (i.e., the general topic), and progressively get more specific and targeted (i.e., up until the specific hypotheses).</p> 

:::

:::


:::



## Method {.smaller}

::: callout-tip
The purpose of this section is to provide a **recipe** for your research so that someone can **replicate** and **evaluate** the results.
:::

The Method section is divided in 3 subsections:

:::{.fragment}
- **Participants:** Demographics and sample composition (e.g., number of participants, mean age and standard deviation, gender, etc...).  
:::

:::{.fragment}
- **Materials:** Usually, here you mention what questionnaires were used to measure the variables. In the case of the lab reports, mention how the variables were measured (e.g., response times were measured in milliseconds).  
:::

:::{.fragment}
- **Procedure:** detail how the lab experiment worked. 
:::


## Results

In the results section, you should present the statistics that test your hypotheses. Here's a short example:


:::{.fragment}
>A two-way ANOVA was performed to evaluate the effects of gender and college major on students’ Research Methods exam scores. The means and standard deviations for students’ Research Methods exam scores were *M* = 81.6 and *SD* = 10.2 respectively. The results indicated no significant main effect for gender, *F*(1, 54) = 0.09, *p* = .771; a significant main effect for major, *F*(2, 54) = 10.52, *p* < .001; and no significant interaction between gender and major, *F*(2, 54) = 0.23, *p* = .795. (taken from [ezspss.com](https://ezspss.com/how-to-report-a-two-way-anova-from-spss-in-apa-style/){target="blank"})

:::



<ul style = "font-size:25px;
             margin: 20px;">
:::{.fragment}
<li>  Do not interpret the results, simply state them. The interpretation comes later. </li>

:::

:::{.fragment}
<li>  Remember to include descriptive statistics (mean and standard deviation) of your variables at the beginning of your result section. </li>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<li>  "F", "p", "M" and "SD", as well as any abbreviation that refers to a statistic must be *italicized*. </li>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<li>  Depending on what analyses you are running, there will be different APA guidelines for reporting results. Either refer to your PSYC 2000 lab slides or consult [this document](https://psych.uw.edu/storage/writing_center/stats.pdf){target="blank"}. </li>
:::

</ul>

   
## Discussion

In the discussion, you should sum up your findings, interpret them, and critically evaluate the experiment:

:::{.fragment}
- Interpret the statistics presented in the Results section. Were the hypotheses supported?
:::

:::{.fragment}
- Why do you think the results were observed? 
:::

:::{.fragment}
- What were some limitations of the experiment?
:::

:::{.fragment}
- What could or should be done in the future?
:::

::: {layout-ncol="2"}

::: {.column width="55%"}

Not much to say here, so just a few quick notes:

:::{.fragment}
- References go in alphabetical order.
:::

:::{.fragment}
- Every reference has a *hanging indent*
:::

:::{.fragment}
- For the purpose of the lab reports, feel free to ignore the DOIs at the end of the references.
:::

## References: Journal Article

At its end, every APA style manuscript should have a "references" section including the full references of all the sources cited in the main text.

[You need to include **three** references in your final paper]{.underline}


The general format for journal article references is:

[Author, A. A., Author, B. B., & Author, C. C.]{.fragment fragment-index="1" style="color: red;"} [(Year of publication).]{.fragment fragment-index="2" style="color: blue;"} [Title of article.]{.fragment fragment-index="3" style="color: orange;"} [*Title of Journal*,]{.fragment fragment-index="4" style="color: magenta;"} [*volume number*]{.fragment fragment-index="5" style="color: grey;"} [(issue number),]{.fragment fragment-index="6" style="color: HotPink;"} [pages.]{.fragment fragment-index="7" style="color: purple;"}

::: callout-note
## Journal Article

::: {.fragment fragment-index="1"}
[Rachlinski, J. J., Guthrie, C., & Wistrich, A. J.]{.fragment fragment-index="1" style="color: red;"} [(2011).]{.fragment fragment-index="2" style="color: blue;"} [Probable Cause, Probability, and Hindsight.]{.fragment fragment-index="3" style="color: orange;"} [*Journal of Empirical Legal Studies*,]{.fragment fragment-index="4" style="color: magenta;"} [*72*]{.fragment fragment-index="5" style="color: green;"}[(51),]{.fragment fragment-index="6" style="color: HotPink;"} [157--180.]{.fragment fragment-index="7" style="color: purple;"} [https://doi-org.libproxy.unl.edu/10.1111/j.1740-1461.2011.01230.x]{.fragment fragment-index="8" style="color: grey;"}
:::

:::


# APA Style Review

::: {layout-ncol="2"}
::: col
:::
:::

## In-text Citations {.smaller}

::: inner-container
::: post-it
For someone's "...ideas, theories, or research..." <br> (APA publication manual, 2019, p. 281).
:::
:::

::: fragment
> Hindsight bias has been demonstrated in a variety of legal decision-making settings (Harley, 2007).

:::

::: fragment
Basic format for an In-text citation is *(author(s) name(s), publication year)*. When the source has *3 or more authors*, you should just cite the first author followed by *et. al*:

> Researchers have demonstrated that outcome knowledge can distort perceptions of either the foreseeability or the inevitability of an event (Blank **et al.**, 2015).
:::

::: fragment
Finally, you can also cite someone by using them as the sentence subject:

> **Blank et al. (2015)** discussed how children with autism spectrum disorder are often very selective about what food they will eat and experience difficulties during mealtimes.
:::

## Multiple In-text citations & </br> Direct quotes {.smaller}

::: fragment
Sometimes, you need to cite multiple sources to back up one of your statements. If so, remember that the sources should be *ordered alphabetically* and separated by a "*;*":

> Studies demonstrate that hindsight bias can occur in various contexts (**B**lank & Peters, 2010; **C**hristensen--Szalanski & Willham, 1991; **H**arley, 2007; **F**ischhoff, 1975, 1977).
:::

</br>

::: fragment
**Direct quotes** from other sources function very similar to in-text citations, but have a few differences; when the quote is *under 40 words*, the only addition necessary is enclosing the sentence within *quotations* and including the *page number*:

According to a recent paper, "quotes can be useful in academic writing" (Singh et al., 2019**, p. 25**).
:::

::: fragment
When the quote is *over 40 words*, you need to enclose the sentence within a [block-quote](https://www.scribbr.com/working-with-sources/block-quote/){target="_blank"}.

However, I don't think that this case should come up in your lab reports.
:::


## Numbers {.smaller}

::: body
1.  Always spell out numbers when the number in question is not a statistic, below 10 OR is at the beginning of a line (e.g., "two" instead of "2"). Always use numerals for 10 or above.

2.  Round all numbers to **2 decimal places**. However, always round **p-values** to **3 decimal place**.

3.  Use a leading 0 only for numbers that can be larger than 1. For example, correlations and *p*-values can only range between -1/1 and 0/1 respectively, and do not need a leading 0 (e.g., "*r* = .57" instead of "*r* = 0.57")
:::

## Abbreviations

Abbreviations can be used for words that are repeated throughout a paper BUT:

</br>

::: fragment
MUST clearly explain the **FIRST** time the full word is presented, and then **ONLY** use the abbreviation afterwards. 

> The **Causal Model Theory (CMT)** of hindsight bias suggests that it will only occur in situations where the outcome information can be linked conceptually to the events that proceeded it. However, the CMT also

:::

::: {.callout-warning .fragment}
Abrevs can b confusing, so do this sparingly. 
:::
